title: At close of business on 16 March 2022, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 26 January 2022?
preds:
The Federal Reserve is widely expected to raise interest rates tomorrow to help tame inflation. 
But is there a possibility that the current instability resulting from the Russia-Ukraine conflict, prices of oil (which did go down today), and China back on lockdown for some major cities, which could affect already serious supply chain issues, would hold back the hike? 
The stock market saw gains today despite yesterday's steep loses for the Nasdaq (recovered 3/16%) and Goldman Sachs cutting the yearly outlook for the S&P. S&P closed up 2.14%, Dow up 1.82%. One can assume this response is due in great part to expected hike raise tomorrow.

Base rate for past 24 months (since March 2020) is near zero - <0.10% - FFR. At the outset of the pandemic the FFR was decreased to near zero and has remained there. 
https://www.macrotrends.net/2015/fed-funds-rate-historical-chart  Signal: significant telegraphing by Jerome Powell and the FOMC regarding FFR increase to cool inflation. There is currently a 99.8% probability, according to the CME FedWatch Tool, that the rate will be increased between .25-.50 basis points at the 16 MAR 2022 meeting of the FOMC. https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html#
following @mattlerner 's advice and factoring in a slight chance that war will cause the Fed to take pause.

Based off of the articles that I found, I do believe that the Federal Funds Rate will increase at the close of business on March 16, 2022. Both of the articles from Reuters and the article from AP News all state that U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Powell have stated that he is going to push for an increase during the March meeting (Rugaber, 2022) (Reuters, 2022) (Schneider, 2022). According to the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the AP News article the Federal Funds Rate increases in order to tempter economic growth and to cool off inflation (Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System n.d.). One of the items that might prevent the Federal Fund Rate from increasing is economic uncertainty and that can currently be seen through the Ukrainian Conflict. However, Powell still states that the Federal Funds Rate will increase despite this conflict (Schneider, 2022).   References:   Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System (US), Federal Funds Effective Rate [FEDFUNDS], retrieved from FRED, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis; https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDFUNDS, March 6, 2022.  Chen, J., (2022, January 27) Federal Funds Rate. Investopedia. https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/federalfundsrate.asp  Rugaber C., (2022 January 26) Fed Plans to Raise Rates Starting in March to Cool Inflation. AP News. https://apnews.com/article/federal-reserve-interest-rates-inflation-1dd9283e46162b3c0d29a2c55a2934d1  Reuters. (2022, March 2) Fed's Powell Says Still Appropriate to Raise Interest Rates by 25 bps in March. Reuters. https://www.reuters.com/business/feds-powell-says-still-appropriate-raise-interest-rates-by-25-bps-march-2022-03-02/  Schneider, H., (2022, March 3) Fed’s Powell: Ukraine War Impact Uncertain but Could Hit Spending Investment. Reuters.  https://www.reuters.com/business/feds-powell-ukraine-war-impact-uncertain-could-hit-spending-investment-2022-03-03/

Based on the trends in recent months, it appears that the rate has remained relatively consistent fluctuating by only .1 every so often. For the past 5 months, the rate has remained at .8. However, one thing to consider is that the efficient fund rate is affected by employment, inflation, current conflicts, and political standings. Therefore, after evaluating the inflation rate within the past couple of months it appears that that has had a slight impact on the federal funds rate. Based on current situations, there are articles stating that the rate was expected to rise as much as .5. However, due to the situation that currently is happening between Russia and Ukraine, the government is only expected to increase it about .25 and go from there. https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/federalfundsrate.asp#:~:text=The%20federal%20funds%20rate%20is,reserves%20to%20each%20other%20overnight.&text=The%20federal%20funds%20rate%20can,consumer%20loans%20and%20credit%20cards. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDFUNDS https://www.reuters.com/business/fed-raise-rates-wont-be-restrictive-90s-evans-2022-03-04/

As of March 2, 2022 the Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell has indicated that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at it’s March 15-16, 2022 meeting.  Cristopher Rugaber, “Powell Tells Congress That Fed Will Raise Rates This Month,” https://www.inquirer.com, accessed March 6, 2022, https://www.inquirer.com/economy/interest-rates-higher-federal-reserve-jerome-powell-20220302.html.

At the close of business on 26 January 2022, the upper limit of the Federal Reserve’s target range for the federal funds rate was at 0.25% (or 25 basis points). This limit has been in place since March 16, 2020. This was the same rate in place from 2008 until the end of 2015. Between 2015 and March 2020, the rate fluctuated to as high as 2.5% between December 2018 to July 2019.  Inflation is inversely correlated to the federal funds rate in a system of fractional reserve banking, which the United States has. Inflation can be measured by the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Between the higher target range of 2.5% federal funds rate of 2015 and March 2020, CPI varied only between 0% and 2.5%. And yet the Federal Open Market Committee regularly raised and lowered the federal funds rate during this time. In the last year, inflation is undergoing a much more radical change from 1.35% to 7.5%. During this time, the federal funds rate upper limit has not changed from .25%. However, such a sharp uptick in inflation would indicate a higher likelihood of an increased target. A clue is given by the FMOC regarding this matter. In a press release on January 26, the FMOC said “. With inflation well above 2 percent and a strong labor market, the Committee expects it will soon be appropriate to raise the target range for the federal funds rate.” The question is whether “soon” could be assumed to be the next meeting of the committee with a decision to go into effect on March 16, or if “soon” means some other point in 2022. Forecasters from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia predict a higher near-term inflation rate of 5.5%, compared to an expected average of 2.5% over the next decade. Because of this continued indication of higher-than-average near-term inflation, I predict that the FMOC will raise the upper limit of the Federal Reserve’s target range for the federal funds rate on March 16, 2022. Sources: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU
https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/12/inflation-interest-rate-relationship.asp
https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/monetary20220126a.htm

After getting a general idea of what the target range is, I decided to break down the question a bit.  At first glance, there are three options so without any analysis that would offer a 33.3% chance of each occurring.  However, in my initial research I learned that the current target range is set at 0-25 basis points so essentially rock bottom.  I also noticed in looking at the historical data that the target range is generally adjusted in 0.25% or 25 basis point increments.  Given that, I would estimate there is little to no chance of the upper limit going lower, allowing me to rule out one of the three possibilities here.  The next step in my research was to examine the historical data for trends and volatility.  Given that the deadline for this question is relatively close (currently about two weeks) it would be important to know how often the rate fluctuates up or down and if those changes were connected to specific historical events.  According to the website of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the target range held steady at 0-.25% from mid-December 2008 until mid-December 2015 at which point it entered a period of relative volatility mostly increasing until mid-July 2019, then slowly declining until mid-March 2020 at which point it returned to the rock bottom 0-.25% where it currently stands.  Based on that preliminary assessment my initial thought was that the rate is likely to stay the same given it has been rock bottom for almost two years.  Since historical data shows a relatively sharp drop coinciding with the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic, I would think that is a significant factor for the rate being so low for so long.  As part of a class discussion, I learned of a transcript from a 26 January 2022 press conference with Federal Reserve Chair Powell in which he stated, “…an increase in this rate would soon be appropriate.”  Given that the economy and life in general are starting to open back up recently, that would seem to track with a potential target rate increase.  Even after reading the transcript, I was still thinking there was a chance the upper limit could stay the same (.25%) due to uncertainty around the Russian invasion of Ukraine however that was mainly a guess and not based on any specific analysis.  A New York Times article from 3 March 2022 on this topic, explains that the war in Ukraine is likely to “push up gas and other commodity prices further elevating inflation”.  Because it was explained in the transcript from 26 January 2022 that one of the goals of a rate hike would be to help bring inflation under control, I now feel more confident that the upper limit will be higher at COB on 16 March 2022 than it was at COB on 26 January 2022. Resources:         https://www.federalreserve.gov/mediacenter/files/FOMCpresconf20220126.pdf https://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/reference-rates/effr https://www.nytimes.com/2022/03/03/business/economy/federal-reserve-powell-inflation.html
Adjusting down a bit, as the Ukraine war I think makes this a bit less likely.
Powell implied a .25% hike would be acceptable to Congress March 2nd.

The strategy has been announced. Of course there is a chance that something will cause a deviation from the plan, but I think it's far less than half a percent at this point, so I'm rounding up to 100%.

The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) determines the federal fund rate. The federal fund rate is the interest rate at which banks lend money with accounts at the Federal Reserve and sets the base rate for borrowing costs (federalreserve.gov, 2022). The Federal Chair Jerome Powell told Congress Wednesday the central bank plans to raise the interest rate to curb inflation. A quarter-point is likely to be approved by the Fed’s policy-making committee. According to Powell inflation is well above 2% and raising the rate is an important action.  Most other Fed officials agree with Powell's decision to raise the federal fund rate. Powell states that it will take time to get U.S. inflation under control, and the situation in Ukraine and the U.S. economy factor to how the response is. Powell spoke with President Biden the day after his State of the Union speech and Powell’s top priority was to get prices under control. It is likely the federal fund rate will be higher than it was at the close of business on 26 January 2022.

Powell will be talking to Congress in a few days, we may hear a clearer direction then. https://www.bloombergquint.com/global-economics/powell-seeks-to-reassure-lawmakers-fed-will-curb-hot-inflation Goldman Sachs Group are still forecasting multiple hikes for the year that have not happened yet.

https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-02-28/goldman-raises-u-s-inflation-forecasts-sees-more-hikes-in-2023

Outside of a four-year window the upper limit has been .25 https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU  Past performance rates are not a clear indicator of future rates but it is a good place to start.

More likely to be a 25 bps than 50 bps hike, given the Ukraine situation. But inflation is still a very real concern, and they wouldn't want to look like they're doing nothing about it. 2% probably on 2nd bucket, given talk of thermobaric bombs and what I see as a non-zero chance of Putin doing something crazy as things look more desperate for him.

To answer this question, I conducted an internet search of “Federal Reserve’s target range for the federal funds rate.” There were two sources of value for answering this question. First, the Federal Reserve website was an obvious choice to research the topic. On their website, it showed the Federal Open Market Committee (headed by Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell) lowered the Federal Reserve’s target range for the federal funds rate between 0.00% and 0.25% back in March 2020 due to the COVID19 virus (federalreserve.org). I discovered transcripts of a conference Chair Powell had on January 26, 2022 wherein (when asked) he stated the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) was considering of raising the federal funds rate at their next meeting on March 2022 depending on certain conditions (Investopedia.com). However, because the economy is slowing due to inflation, I believe the FOMC will keep the federal funds rate where they are at (thebalance.com).
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/2182-at-close-of-business-on-16-march-2022-will-the-upper-limit-of-the-federal-reserve-s-target-range-for-the-federal-funds-rate-be-lower-the-same-or-higher-than-it-was-at-close-of-business-on-26-january-2022 (Links to an external site.)
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/f/federalfundsrate.asp
https://www.thebalance.com/current-federal-reserve-interest-rates-4770718

The Fed has been hinting and warning that a rate hike has been coming for a while now, and with inflation running very hot and COVID restrictions ending it only seems only reasonable that the most logical step is to start coming off of the emergency low interest rates. I would expect a .25 or .5 increase to the feds fund rate at the march meeting. The only reason same has a 10% probability is to cover the case where the Fed gets spooked by the possible how sanctions caused by the Ukraine situation may affect the economy and wait a little longer to begin liftoff. Certainly an increased chance of no movement compared to a few weeks ago.
The rates have stayed relatively level, small margins up and down.

Fed governors and presidents have been consistently hawkish over the past few months. The argument now is whether they will hike 25 or 50bps. 1% chance of an external shock like new severe Covid strain or Russia/Ukraine war

I think that the Federal Reserve knows that they are trapped and they are not really in a position to raise rates even though they need to. The conflict in Ukraine can give them the excuse they need to not raise rates.

I believe that at close of business in March of 2022 the upper limited will be higher than it was in January 2022. The historical data points that in times of great recession the FED lowers the federal funds rate to allow for more fluidity in the marketplace and attempts to stimulate the economy in this manner. Forbes notes about these actions in the 2008 lending crisis. ”In 2008, the Federal Reserve lowered the fed funds rate to 0%, to revive the economy during the Great Recession. It did so once again in 2020 to minimize the economic fallout from the Covid-19 crisis. Lower rates make lending and credit easier for borrowers to get, which spurs consumer and business spending and grows the economy.” This practice is very cyclical in manner as the FEDs once again lowered rates to during an economic crisis and was followed by a rate raise once the economy becomes more stabilized. A look at what rates immediately prior to the 2020 pandemic could provide a good gauge into the fiscal mindset of the economy without an immediate crisis occurring. “To provide more accommodation during the financial crisis of 2007–08 and the accompanying Great Recession, the FOMC cut the federal funds rate to its effective lowest level, where it remained until December 2015. Over the next three years, the FOMC increased rates very gradually to 2.25 to 2.5 percent in December 2018. The Committee maintained that range until July 2019 when, citing the implications of global developments for the economic outlook and muted inflation pressures, the FOMC voted to reduce the federal funds rate range by 25 basis points. The Committee reduced the range an additional 25 basis points in September 2019 and again in October 2019.” As these indications talk about a range far above the target 0.25 top end that is currently in discussion. This along with rising inflation rates the highest since the 1980s the FED is going to feel political leverage to provide relief. O'Connell, B. (2022, January 10). Understanding the federal funds rate. Forbes. Retrieved February 20, 2022, from https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/federal-funds-rate/  The federal funds rate. The Federal Funds Rate - Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. (n.d.). Retrieved February 20, 2022, from https://www.chicagofed.org/research/dual-mandate/the-federal-funds-rate

Given recent inflation prints, Fed commentary, and action in bond market, I am increasingly confident in them lifting off in March. The 2% on same is reserved for a black swan events (Russia/Ukraine, another variant) that stops the move.
Very likely to represent an increase, unless after time of writing geopolitical disruptions cause the board to delay a rate rise
Eurodollar futures markets are now pricing a 0.50% rate increase at the March meeting and a 25% chance that a rate hike happens between FOMC meetings.
Updating way up here as my prediction about this month's inflation numbers, e.g. that inflation would start to subside, have proven false. I think the Fed will have no choice but to raise rates here.

The Federal Reserve has shown historical reluctance to chance Federal monetary policy in the wake of increasing inflation [1], preferring to remain steady in face of future potential variants.[2] Recently however, the Federal Reserve called for an increase in interest rates [3]. The inflation rate has been higher than expected, even when adjusting for several years of no inflation before the pandemic. The Fed has been signaling that it would raise interest rates to cool the economy. There has been debate about when the Fed would raise rates and how many times they would raise interest rates this year. The Fed has signaled that it's looking to raise rates in March https://www-nytimes-com.nduezproxy.idm.oclc.org/2022/01/26/business/economy/fed-interest-rates-inflation.html
Jerome Powell has stated that interest rates will increase beginning March 2022 barring any unforeseeable events.

Inflation is quickly rising. The FED is playing catch-up to this game.
Indirect effects of rising energy costs to the entire economy are working their way through the economy and will end up in even higher inflation.

Given the messaging from the Fed (Powell et co) and the wisdom of markets (not only here but in the WIRP on Bloomberg -- which indicates the probability per options) I'm confident that the Fed is going to hike in March, not withstanding any severe changes over the next six weeks (inflation / geopolitical wise). It's really a matter of 25bps or 50bps in my view.
1% = chance of a renewed recession in the next 45 days

Current effective Fed rate = 0.08% [1]
March 30 day fed future trading at 0.235% effective [2]
Using following method [3]
Assuming 80% chance of 25 bp increase, 20% chance of 50 bp increase if increase occurs
=> ~84% chance of increase [1] = https://www.newyorkfed.org/markets/reference-rates/effr

Updating again on signaling of rate hikes, but not that high

Updating up a bit on this CNBC article (https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/25/the-federal-reserve-is-likely-to-signal-a-march-rate-hike.html) which makes the point that 2015 is the appropriate reference class here.
Up to follow the crowd until we hear what the FED has to say Wednesday.

The question is what is more important, the stock market or inflation. The FED has already made it pretty clear they are not going to fight inflation, since inflation is at 7% annual and interest rates are still at 0% and they are still easing by buying assets. So the FED is still, at this moment, pouring gasoline on the inflation fire. The S&P is down at this point into correction territory, and the Russell 2000 is into bear market territory. Bitcoin is down to 50% of its high level. I don't see the FED raising the federal funds rate at this point.

I don't think the taper will be anywhere close to over by March, but it's not crazy to think the Fed will still raise rates to maintain credibility regarding its fight against inflation, especially with the market pricing in such a high probability of a hike.
March 2022 Eurodollar futures contract is currently pricing an 88% chance.

It's difficult to find systematic data, but I went looking for some reference classes. - In December 2018, the Fed hiked interest rates and forecast two rate increases for 2019 (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/12/19/fed-hikes-rates-by-a-quarter-point-.html). In reality, they lowered rates three times (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU). - Per this Brookings article (https://www.brookings.edu/blog/ben-bernanke/2016/11/28/federal-reserve-economic-projections/), at the tail end of 2015, participants forecast four rate increases in 2016; in reality, there was one. The Brookings piece says that "SEP rate projections over longer horizons have been too optimistic about the ability of the economy to sustain rate increases." - In March 2018, the general expectation (https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/21/fed-hikes-rates-by-a-quarter-point-at-chair-powells-first-meeting.html) was three hikes i 2018, that seemed to be about spot on. So I don't want to overweight the fact that both the market and FOMC projects see hikes on the horizon. I'm updating a bit, but not a lot.

Switching my forecast and may update further again in future - I note that when the Fed last raised interest rates from a low base, the unemployment rate was higher than it is now, which makes me think they won't have any problem raising it in March even if inflation is low.

This source which seems be be based on some kind of market is currently at 90% chance of a hike in March. Seems pretty overconfident and I'd be interested to know if this source has an accurate track record, but going up a little more for now. https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html#
Tilting toward higher as other sources seem to think a March rate hike is likely.

Bill Ackman calling for "shock & awe" and CME predicting an 82% chance of a March hike (79% chance of 25bps, 3% chance of 50bps) I'm moving higher to align with market expectations. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-federal-reserve-needs-to-shock-and-awe-the-market-with-one-big-rate-hike-to-restore-its-credibility-says-hedge-fund-star-bill-ackman-11642357378?mod=home-page

communication from fed along with market pricing of interest rate hikes strongly suggests moving toward March rate hike, will update after january fomc meeting if needed but nearly a lock at this point

Okay! I've been afraid of these questions but I suppose it's worth a try. - Here's the first thing to know: the Fed has realllllly only raised rates once in the past ten years. Yes, if you look at the history (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU) there were a bunch of discrete rate hikes, but we basically had a flat rate of 0.25 for ten years, before the Fed hiked it in December 2015. Inflation was persistently low for that period, so I imagine the Fed's attitude was "why mess with success?" So, if inflation were low, I wouldn't expect a change. - Obviously things are a little different now; we're at 7% annual inflation and 0.5% month-over-month (December), which is importantly a 0.3-percentage-point decrease from November. It seems like normal month-to-month inflation is around 0.2-0.3%, which makes sense because that adds up to about 2-4%, which I understand to be in the desirable range. - The Fed's position is that the current inflation is caused by supply bottlenecks, NOT by too much money supply. If they unduly restrict the money supply, then once supply bottlenecks ease it will be more difficult to get credit, which could cause a contraction right as we need a recovery - and with what I perceive to be the Fed's new comparative focus on full employment relative to inflation, that seems like it's not that likely. - Yes, I get that we're apparently at full employment already. But wages are rising and it's not clear to me that curbing inflation is worth risking that from the perspective of a comparatively (with earlier generations) progressive Fed. - Yes, Fed governors are saying that they expect rate increases. But on the theory that inflation expectations lead to inflation, this seems as likely to be an attempt to curb inflation expectations as a genuine forecast. If they're focusing on messaging intended to curb inflation expectations, that may suggest they expect fundamentals that cause inflation to slow. - I think this will all change if January inflation numbers don't show continued improvement and a return to normal month-on-month inflation rates. If January seasonally adjusted inflation remains high, then I'll adjust my forecast. But I don't think the Fed will raise rates in the next two weeks. For now, I think a rate hike in March is more unlikely than likely, but not by much

Looks increasingly likely that the Fed is behind the 8-ball on inflation and will have to move quicker or more often than they originally expected. Omicron will have less economic impact than feared and inflation will persist longer than thought, all of which opens the door to a quick taper and March increase.

Changing my mind on this. Looks like both analysts and market participants are placing significant probability on a March hike -  https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html . Besides, the March meeting is a "live" one for major policy changes - with a Summary of Economic Projections by the FOMC participants and a press-conference by the chair.  What can lead to a no-change in March? A notable slowdown in inflation in Jan-Feb, a sharp rise in bond yields (so the Fed can argue that the markets are doing their job for them), a market crash, or a sharp economic slowdown.

Sounds like the first hike is very likely to be either March or May. The taper ends in March. I lean toward them not raising rates immediately at the conclusion of the taper, but the FED does seem likely to move pretty quick on raising rates.

As mentioned in my previous forecast,  there is at least 1 in 2 chance of rate increase.
https://www.gjopen.com/questions/2135-at-close-of-business-on-26-january-2022-will-the-upper-limit-of-the-federal-reserve-s-target-range-for-the-federal-funds-rate-be-lower-the-same-or-higher-than-it-was-at-close-of-business-on-15-december-2021

Tapering could be done by March, after which the Fed could raise rates. It will depend on if there is any sign inflation has eased.  The current target rate has been in place since March 2020, so there is some inertia there. But inflation is higher than it's been since the 1970s, so it's hard to see how they can ignore that.

Waiting to see how much tightening is caused by the taper itself.

Inflation is running uncomfortably high for the Fed. With a stubbornly difficult labor market and continued supply chain issues, wage inflation will likely continue at this pace or accelerate into early 2022. This could drive the Fed to finish asset purchases by March, opening the door for a potential hike at the March meeting.
The FED said they will rise three times next year.....
Market appears to think the first rate hike in May is more likely than not.
Seems like the FED will think it's too soon for a hike but upping the odds 5%.
Inflation is higher than normal, but not surging. The Fed plans to take thier time and telegraph thier actions. They will likley raise rates in 2022 but later in the year
If they touch the rates, it is game over, the leverage that they have created is so large that the 1929 decline is going to look like a Dimanche a L'ile de la Jette.
an acceleration in tightening process would have taper concluding in march potentially, but likely would be May or June for initial hike if that was the desired policy path.  very unlikely

The obvious answer would be same or higher.  But there are a number of factors that could lead to lower economic growth and tamer inflation.  A good example would be a dramatic cut-back in the child support payments, which would slow spending and inflation.  The federal government budget will also move toward balance, due both to higher taxes and slower “pandemic” spending.

Some monetary policy tightening is overdue, but the Fed seems to be quite reluctant to proceed with it. They will eventually have to bump the Fed Funds rate higher,  but they might be slower to do it than many people expect.
Adjusting down 5 on same, if another month or two like October numbers hit the FED might move quickly and I think the chance of that is closer to 15% or so.
The new variant will just be the latest in the series of excuses that the Fed has to leave interest rates low

Unemployment is close but still below the current target of 4.0% (output gap remains).  From the Sept meeting, FED assesses inflation as more transitory (than systemic) and driven by supply-chain (versus monetary expansion policy).  Expect taper to conclude before FED interest rate targets change.  Key date is if FED changes outlook at the next policy meeting on 15 Dec.  Potential changes are if PCE rate increases >10%  and if FED Chair changes.  Assess as possible, but not probable.
95% the Fed does exactly what said they were going to do.
Going up on higher due to the high October inflation.
The passage of the IIJA makes a March rate hike a little more likely (contractionary monetary policy to offset the expansionary fiscal policy during a time of inflation).

Eight meetings next year and expected # of rate hikes are slightly above 2 (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/28/the-market-is-starting-to-price-in-more-interest-rate-hikes-than-the-fed-is-indicating.html). This puts initial rate at ~30% of being raised at a given meeting next year. I'm not sure if March is more or less likely than other meetings to have that rate hike but with inflation as high as it is I would err on the side of earlier in the year rather than later so bumping up to 38%

Raising the rate :
More expensive to borrow
Lowers the supply of available money
Increases the short-term interest rates
Keeps inflation in check.  Lowering the rate will do the reverse/ push short-term interest rates down. Watch the changes in CPI,inflation rate, coupled with if open jobs are being filled for the next few months and a better prediction will come. Patrick Harker (pres of the fed bank of Philadelphia) recently spoke on the economy and it certainly doesn’t sound like he’s too worried. “I am acutely aware that this period of rising prices is painful for many Americans. But I do expect inflation to moderate next year as supply chains come back online and bottlenecks ease.” (link below) https://www.philadelphiafed.org/community-development/workforce-and-economic-development/211108-the-economic-club-of-new-york FOMC had a few telling statements on 2021-11-03: “Inflation is elevated, largely reflecting factors that are expected to be transitory. “ “Progress on vaccinations and an easing of supply constraints are expected to support continued gains in economic activity and employment as well as a reduction in inflation“ “The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of 2 percent over the longer run. With inflation having run persistently below this longer-run goal, the Committee will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer‑term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent. “ “The Committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and expects it will be appropriate to maintain this target range until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee's assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.” (link below) https://www.federalreserve.gov/newsevents/pressreleases/monetary20211103a.htm

As the economy recovers and covid decreases I believe the fed will raise the rate but the questions are when will they raise rates and then how fast. During the recovery from 2008 the first step up lasted for a year. After that it was raised about every three months. If they make any move up in Dec I will probably push Same even stronger as it would be the first tentative step and they will want to be cautious. If they have not made a move by Dec and the economy is still on track than I will move to Higher.

Last week, the Federal Reserve’s decision to reduce tapering points towards inflation not being as temporary as thought. As spoken to in the article from Investopedia, I don’t see the fed increasing rates while still tapering. https://www.investopedia.com/fed-will-start-tapering-in-december-2021-5208392 There is concern that the infrastructure package passed by Congress on Friday will increase inflation. I agree with Moody’s assessment that the package will not increase GDP enough to affect inflation dramatically. https://www.moodysanalytics.com/-/media/article/2021/macroeconomic-consequences-of-the-infrastructure-investment-and-jobs-act-and-build-back-better-framework.pdf I see tapering, economies reopening, supply chains improving, and innovation as deflationary pressures that will allow the Fed time to raise rates in the middle to late 2022.  I am leaving room for a rate increase in my forecast because of numerous unknowns (possible change out of Powell as the Federal Reserve Chairman on 4 Feb 22, unexpected inflation data).
Fed is on a steady rise in rates through mid 2022.
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU [I believe it'll be fixed at .25 for 2022] https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/FEDFUNDS
